newsitem.title: INDIA: Ford says hopes "to be best" in India auto market.
newsitem.headline: Ford says hopes "to be best" in India auto market.

text.p: The chief of U.S. car giant Ford Motor Company said on Monday that it was bracing itself to face India's competitive automobile market and hoped to be "the best among competitors".
"It is going to be a very competitive market, but we are confident given the people, technology and quality we are going to be the best among competitors," Alex Trotman said.
Asked if there was room for everyone in India's crowded car market where several foreign manufacturers are pitching in to grab a share of the growing demand, he said: "Probably not."

Trotman was speaking to reporters at this western Indian city of Nashik, 225 km (140 miles) northeast of Bombay, at a ceremony to mark the launch of Ford's first Indian made car at the company's joint venture plant.
The Ford Escort is produced by a joint venture between Ford and India's Mahindra & Mahindra, each owning 50 percent equity.
The Ford chief said the company had no plans to raise its holding in Mahindra Ford India Ltd.
"We are satisfied with equity relations with the partner and don't wish to change that," he said.
Responding to a reporter's query if Ford has plans to launch an Asia-specific vehicle, Trotman said:
"We are studying that kind of vehicle. Yes, quite a bit of advanced work is going on, on that kind of vehicle."
The firm expects to put a price tag on the Ford Escort next week, John Parker, president and managing director of the joint venture firm said.
"It will be competitively priced with Ceilo and Esteem," Parker said.
Ceilo is manufactured by DCM-Daewoo, a joint venture between India's DCM group and South Korea's Daewoo Motor, a unit of Daewoo Group.
Esteem is produced by Maruti Udyog, a venture between the Indian government and Japan's Suzuki Motor Corp.
The Mahindra Ford plant has a capacity to make 25,000 cars annually and it has plans to set up a second unit in southern Tamil Nadu state.
It is initially launching four models of Ford Escort followed by Siesta.
"We haven't decided," said Trotman when asked if more models would be launched. "In ten years we would have half a dozen of Ford vehicles in India."
